I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested support to 
respond to the needs of vulnerable children through support from social workers in the delivery of 
services to vulnerable children. The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
will support the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) to develop policy recommendations which will 
strengthen social work services for vulnerable children through (i) research on international 
experience, (ii) development of guidelines for service standards, and (iii) training requirements for 
social workers.1 This will help improve the social protection system for vulnerable children and 
ensure that their needs are better met.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy 
for the PRC, 2016–2020,2 the Social Protection Operational Plan, 2014–2020,3 and is included in 
the PRC country operations business plan, 2017–2019.4 The TA is also aligned with the PRC 
Thirteenth Five-Year Plan which states that there will be sustained commitment to “provide care, 
psychological counseling, and other services for children in need” in addition to “providing special 
care for left-behind children in rural areas.”5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The PRC has been experiencing rapid demographic and social change as a result of 
economic growth since the 1980s. The shift from a centrally planned to a market-based economy 
in 1978 led to rapid economic and social development, with an average gross domestic product 
growth of nearly 10% since 1978, and nearly 800 million people being pulled out of poverty.6 This 
rapid growth has, however, brought with it a set of challenges and new vulnerabilities, especially 
for children, including increased inequality, pockets of persistent poverty, and changing family 
structures driven in part by rapid urbanization, internal migration, and industrialization. One such 
vulnerability  due  to  regionally  unbalanced  economic  growth,  specific  to  the  PRC,  is  a 
consequence of rural–urban migration and the hukou system,7 where children are left behind in 
rural areas by parents in search of better employment opportunities. Despite significant reductions 
in the number of children left-behind over the past few years, this is still a substantial issue.8 This 
remains one vulnerability facing children, though many others exist including unequal opportunity, 
poverty, and inequality. 
 
4.  Unbalanced economic growth has created a group of children who are vulnerable because 
of poverty, disability, special needs, or failing parental care. In the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, the 
PRC has outlined plans to promote better care and protection for vulnerable children “living in 
difficulties.” This is defined as children left behind by parents, those living in poverty, those living 
with disability, orphans, and children without parental care. Most recently, in 2016, PRC State

2   
Council Order No. 36: Opinions on Strengthening the Guarantee for Destitute Children outlined 
the need for social work to help rehabilitate and improve the lives of vulnerable children.9 
Vulnerable children have special needs and may be neglected for a number of social, political, 
and economic reasons. The purpose of this TA is to help MOCA develop the necessary policies 
and social work system which will be able to support vulnerable children across all of the 
categories adduced above, to ensure their well-being and opportunities in society.  
 
5.  Lessons. ADB has been involved in assisting the PRC and MOCA in developing their 
social protection programs through several TA projects, including Strategies for Involving Social 
Workers in Social Assistance10 and Social Work Services Policy and Delivery Modes for the 
Elderly with Special Difficulties.11 Both these projects (i) reflect the ongoing collaborative effort to 
develop  the  area  of  social  work  as  a  necessary  support  for  vulnerable  groups  and  as  a 
professional occupation well embedded in the social protection system; and (ii) provide valuable 
lessons on (a) the importance of assessing social work services for different vulnerable groups, 
(b) properly planning for the development of social work services, and (c) developing standards 
and  trainings  for  social  workers.  The  area  of  social  work  for  vulnerable  children  is  still 
underdeveloped and in need of rapid improvement.  
 
6.  MOCA seeks to expand the role of social workers in providing social assistance to 
vulnerable children. To accomplish this, systems are necessary to better define the needed 
services, link social workers to vulnerable children, and train social workers appropriately on how 
to deal with special issues arising for vulnerable child populations. Several key issues require 
attention to promote engagement of social workers in reaching and assisting vulnerable children. 
First, a strong policy framework and recommendations for strategies to strengthen social work 
services for vulnerable children are needed. Second, guidelines for service models of engaging 
social workers to assist vulnerable children need to be developed. Third, guidelines on training 
requirements for social workers to manage and work with vulnerable children are needed. And 
fourth, an assessment report for an information technology system to coordinate and manage 
social work services has to be crafted. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: policy environment for social work services 
for vulnerable children strengthened (PRC State Council Order No. 36: Opinions on Strengthening 
the Guarantee for Destitute Children) (footnote 9). The TA will have the following outcome: social 
work system for vulnerable children strengthened.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
 
8.  Output 1: Policy recommendations and operational guidelines on strengthening 
social work services for vulnerable children developed. The TA will review international and

3   
national literature and prior and ongoing experience in the PRC surrounding social worker 
engagement in providing services to vulnerable children. The study report should focus on policies, 
financing options and scope of service delivery, quality, and safety monitoring with a specific 
section on gender analysis. The study report should also seek to understand, discuss, and 
analyze how the PRC’s economic transformation has affected current policies for vulnerable 
children, in addition to considering existing estimates of the number of vulnerable children within 
the country and, if possible, trends in the data across years. The study report will be disseminated 
to policy makers and practitioners from MOCA departments. The TA will study the needs of 
vulnerable children in the PRC with gender-specific issues highlighted, and identify and prepare 
guidelines and an implementation framework for social work services and their delivery. The TA 
will facilitate an international study tour in identified countries where there has been best practice 
in designing social work services for vulnerable children. Relevant officials of the ministry and 
bureaus of civil affairs will be consulted on the countries of greatest relevance for the PRC, where 
there can be some learnings gleaned. In addition, the TA will develop guidelines on training needs 
for social workers who will work with vulnerable children. The guidelines will provide a framework 
on training needs in areas where social workers should be trained to support vulnerable children.  
 
9.  Output  2:  Assessment  report  of  potential  information  technology  system  and 
database  prepared.  The  TA  will  conduct  a  needs  assessment  for  a  secure  information 
technology database and management system to be set up to coordinate, assess, and manage 
services, and monitor social workers and link them to vulnerable children across rural and urban 
areas with guidance on methods for collecting sex-disaggregated data. The database will be a 
decision support system which is gender responsive. The assessment report will determine the 
financing and other sustainability requirements of a potential database system and all other issues 
to set it up.  
 
10.  Output 3: Awareness of social work services for vulnerable children enhanced. Two 
workshops and a final conference, with participation from central and provincial government 
officials, other international partners, and civil society stakeholders, will be held to discuss and 
disseminate TA findings and policy recommendations. A knowledge product on social work 
services for vulnerable children will be prepared and a final TA report will be submitted to MOCA 
and ADB.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation and 
venues for meetings, counterpart staff and allowances, miscellaneous administration expenses, 
and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The executing agency will be the MOCA and the implementing agency is the Department 
of Social Work. ADB will administer the TA and select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). The TA will be implemented from September 2017 to August 2019.

14.  Consulting services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).12 The consultants 
will  be  selected  based  on  their  academic  qualifications  and  relevant  work  experience.  An 
international consultant and five national consultants will be selected based on their academic 
qualifications and relevant work experience, for total consulting inputs of 32 person-months           
(4 person-months international and 28 person-months national).13
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Policy and Social Work Services for Vulnerable 
Children, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
